answer_html: \(x = \left(\begin{array}{c} ct e^t + b e^t \\ -2 c t e^t + (c-2b) e^t \end{array}\right)\).
hints_html:
If the system is “diagonalized”, it can be solved easily with a linear change of variables.

How does having a diagonalized matrix M such that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}A=SMS^{-1}\end{aligned}\]

help us solve the problem

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}x'=Ax=SMS^{-1}x?\end{aligned}\]

Consider y = S-1x.
hints_latex:
If the system is ``diagonalized'', it can be solved easily with a linear
change of variables.
hints_raw:
If the system is "diagonalized", it can be solved easily with a linear change of variables.
How does having a diagonalized matrix ''M'' such that

:<math>
\displaystyle{}A=SMS^{-1}
</math>

help us solve the problem

:<math>
\displaystyle{}x'=Ax=SMS^{-1}x?
</math>

Consider ''y = S<sup>-1</sup>x''.
question: 6 (b)
sols_html:
__NOTOC__

To begin with we matrix M in Jordan normal form, such that A = SMS-1. To do we need to find the (generalized) eigenvector of A.

Eigenvector v

Knowing \(\lambda = 1\), we will proceed to find our eigenvectors by solving \((A - \lambda I)v = 0\).

\(\left(\begin{array}{cc} 2 & 1 \\ -4 & -2 \end{array}\right) \left(\begin{array}{c} v_1 \\ v_2 \end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{c} 0 \\ 0 \end{array}\right)\)

which gives the homogeneous system

\(\left[\begin{array}{cc} 2 & 1 \\ -4 & -2 \end{array}\right]\).

Placing this in reduced-row form we get

\[\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{cc} 2 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

so that \(v_2 = -2 v_1\). We take

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}v = (1, -2)^T\end{aligned}\]

as the eigenvector.

Unfortunately, we only find one eigenvector from this, and we’ll need to consider generalized eigenvectors and the Jordan canonical form in order to solve this problem.

Find the generalized eigenvector w

The generalized eigenvector satisfies \((A - \lambda I)w = v\) which gives us

\(\left(\begin{array}{cc} 2 & 1 \\ -4 & -2 \end{array}\right) \left(\begin{array}{c} w_1 \\ w_2 \end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ -2 \end{array}\right).\)

Row reductions lead to

\(\left(\begin{array}{cc} 2 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 \end{array}\right) \left(\begin{array}{c} w_1 \\ w_2 \end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\right)\)

which has a solution set that can be parameterized by \(w_1\):

\[\begin{aligned} \left(\begin{array}{c} w_1 \\ 1 - 2w_1 \end{array}\right) = w_1 \left(\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ -2 \end{array}\right) + \left(\begin{array}{c} 0 \\ 1 \end{array}\right).\end{aligned}\]

For simplicity, we can take \(w_1 = 0\) so that our generalized eigenvector is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}w = (0,1)^T.\end{aligned}\]

Setting up the Jordan normal form M

Having found the generalized eigenvector, we get that the matrix A has Jordan Canonical form

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}A = SMS^{-1}\end{aligned}\]

where

\[\begin{aligned} S = \left(\begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0 \\ -2 & 1 \end{array}\right)\end{aligned}\]

is the matrix with columns being the eigenvectors, and

\[\begin{aligned} M = \left(\begin{array}{cc} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{array}\right)\end{aligned}\]

is the matrix with the eigenvalues along the diagonal with 1’s above them.

A quick computation yields

\[\begin{aligned} S^{-1} = \left(\begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0 \\ 2 & 1 \end{array}\right).\end{aligned}\]

Our system states that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}x' = A x\end{aligned}\]

where

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}x = (x_1, x_2)^T.\end{aligned}\]

We can therefore write,

\[\begin{aligned} x' &= SMS^{-1} x\\ S^{-1} x' &= M S^{-1} x\\ y' &= M y\end{aligned}\]

where

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}y = S^{-1} x.\end{aligned}\]

Solve the simplified system y’ = My

The system

\[\begin{aligned} y' = My=\left(\begin{array}{cc} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{array}\right)\begin{pmatrix}y_1\\y_2\end{pmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

tells us

\[\begin{aligned} y_1' &= y_1 + y_2 \\ y_2' &= y_2 \end{aligned}\]

.

The second equation gives us

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}y_2 = c e^t.\end{aligned}\]

Using this in the first equation means

\[\begin{aligned} y_1' &= y_1 + c e^t\\ y_1' - y_1 &= c e^t\\ e^{-t}y_1' - e^{-t}y_1 &= (e^{-t} y_1)' = c\\ e^{-t}y_1 &= ct + b\\ y_1 &= (ct + b) e^t \end{aligned}\]

which has been solved using integrating factors. Now we have

\[\begin{aligned} y = \left(\begin{array}{c} ct e^t + b e^t \\ c e^t \end{array}\right)\end{aligned}\]

Recover the solution x

which immediately gives us our solution x,

\(x = Sy = \left(\begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0 \\ -2 & 1 \end{array}\right) \left(\begin{array}{c} ct e^t + b e^t \\ c e^t \end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{c} ct e^t + b e^t \\ -2 c t e^t + (c-2b) e^t \end{array}\right)\).
sols_raw:
__NOTOC__

To begin with we matrix ''M'' in Jordan normal form, such that ''A = SMS<sup>-1</sup>''. To do we need to find the (generalized) eigenvector of ''A''.

===== Eigenvector ''v'' =====

Knowing <math>\lambda = 1</math>, we will proceed to find our eigenvectors by solving <math>(A - \lambda I)v = 0</math>.

<math>
\left(\begin{array}{cc}
2 & 1 \\ -4 & -2
\end{array}\right) \left(\begin{array}{c}
v_1 \\ v_2
\end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{c}
0 \\ 0
\end{array}\right) 
</math>

which gives the homogeneous system

<math> \left[\begin{array}{cc}
2 & 1 \\ -4 & -2
\end{array}\right] </math>.

Placing this in reduced-row form we get

:<math> \left[\begin{array}{cc}
2 & 1 \\ 0 & 0
\end{array}\right]
</math>

so that <math>v_2 = -2 v_1</math>. We take

:<math>
\displaystyle{}v = (1, -2)^T
</math>

as the eigenvector.

Unfortunately, we only find one eigenvector from this, and we'll need to consider generalized eigenvectors and the Jordan canonical form in order to solve this problem.

===== Find the generalized eigenvector ''w'' =====


The generalized eigenvector satisfies <math>(A - \lambda I)w = v</math> which gives us

<math>
\left(\begin{array}{cc}
2 & 1 \\ -4 & -2
\end{array}\right) \left(\begin{array}{c}
w_1 \\ w_2
\end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{c}
1 \\ -2
\end{array}\right). 
</math>

Row reductions lead to 

<math>
\left(\begin{array}{cc}
2 & 1 \\ 0 & 0
\end{array}\right) \left(\begin{array}{c}
w_1 \\ w_2
\end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{c}
1 \\ 0
\end{array}\right) 
</math>

which has a solution set that can be parameterized by <math>w_1</math>:

:<math>\left(\begin{array}{c}
w_1 \\ 1 - 2w_1
\end{array}\right) = w_1 \left(\begin{array}{c}
1 \\ -2
\end{array}\right) + \left(\begin{array}{c}
0 \\ 1
\end{array}\right).
</math>

For simplicity, we can take <math>w_1 = 0</math> so that our generalized eigenvector is

:<math>
\displaystyle{}w = (0,1)^T.
</math>


===== Setting up the Jordan normal form ''M'' =====

Having found the generalized eigenvector, we get that the matrix A has Jordan Canonical form

:<math>
\displaystyle{}A = SMS^{-1}
</math>

where

:<math>S = \left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & 0 \\ -2 & 1
\end{array}\right)</math> is the matrix with columns being the eigenvectors, and

:<math>M = \left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1
\end{array}\right)</math> is the matrix with the eigenvalues along the diagonal with 1's above them.

A quick computation yields

:<math>S^{-1} = \left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & 0 \\ 2 & 1
\end{array}\right).
</math>

Our system states that

:<math>
\displaystyle{}x' = A x
</math>

where

:<math>
\displaystyle{}x = (x_1, x_2)^T.
</math>

We can therefore write,

:<math>
\begin{align}
x' &= SMS^{-1} x\\
S^{-1} x' &= M S^{-1} x\\
y' &= M y
\end{align}
</math>

where

:<math>
\displaystyle{}y = S^{-1} x
</math>.

===== Solve the simplified system ''y' = My'' =====

The system

:<math>
y' = My=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1
\end{array}\right)\begin{pmatrix}y_1\\y_2\end{pmatrix}
</math>

tells us 

<math>\begin{align} y_1' &= y_1 + y_2 \\ y_2' &= y_2 \end{align} </math>. 

The second equation gives us

:<math>
\displaystyle{}y_2 = c e^t.
</math>

Using this in the first equation means

:<math>
\begin{align}
y_1' &= y_1 + c e^t\\
y_1' - y_1 &= c e^t\\
e^{-t}y_1' - e^{-t}y_1 &= (e^{-t} y_1)' = c\\
e^{-t}y_1 &= ct + b\\
y_1 &= (ct + b) e^t 
\end{align} 
</math>

which has been solved using integrating factors. Now we have

:<math>y = \left(\begin{array}{c}
ct e^t + b e^t \\ c e^t
\end{array}\right)</math>

===== Recover the solution ''x'' =====

which immediately gives us our solution x,

<math>x = Sy = \left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & 0 \\ -2 & 1
\end{array}\right) \left(\begin{array}{c}
ct e^t + b e^t \\ c e^t
\end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{c}
ct e^t + b e^t \\ -2 c t e^t + (c-2b) e^t
\end{array}\right)</math>.
statement_html:
Let

\[\begin{aligned} A = \left(\begin{array}{cc} 3 & 1 \\ -4 & -1 \end{array}\right)\end{aligned}\]

(b) Find the general solution of the system of equations

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x}' = A\mathbf{x}\end{aligned}\]

Here \(\mathbf{x}(t) = \left(\begin{array}{c} x_1(t) \\x_2(t) \end{array}\right)\)
statement_raw:
Let

:<math>
A = \left(\begin{array}{cc}
3 & 1 \\ -4 & -1
\end{array}\right)
</math>

'''(b)''' Find the general solution of the system of equations

:<math>
\mathbf{x}' = A\mathbf{x}
</math>

Here <math> \mathbf{x}(t) = \left(\begin{array}{c} x_1(t) \\ x_2(t) \end{array}\right) </math>
